questions.text: Which among the following can be treated with standard endoscopic mucosal resection in the case of gastroesophageal junction adenocarcinoma?
questions.solution:
The general guidelines for endoscopic resection of early gastroesophageal junction cancer are as follows:

  • Tumour smaller than 2 cm
  • Tumour limited to the mucosa
  • No lymphovascular invasion
  • No ulceration
  • Well- or moderately differentiated histopathology( intestinal type)

If any of these is not fulfilled, gastrectomy with lymph node dissection is indicated.

Option A: Tumour Should be Smaller than 2 cm in size.

Option B: Tumour shouldn't have Lymphovascular Invasion.

Option C: Tumour should be Well to moderately differentiated.

Key Takeaway:

Well to moderately differentiated early GEJ Tumour <2 cm In size, limited to mucosa without Ulceration & Lymphovascular Invasion than Endoscopic resection can be done.

questions.text: A 24 year male patient has undergone upper GI endoscopy for bloody vomitus, he was diagnosed with peptic ulcer disease. The most common vessel that bleeds in peptic ulcer is?
questions.solution:
• The vessel most likely to bleed in peptic ulcer is the gastroduodenal artery because of erosion from a posterior ulcer.
  • Duodenal ulcers are ten times more common than gastric ulcers in young patients, but in the older age groups, the frequency is almost equal.
  • The celiac artery provides most of the blood supply to the stomach. The right gastric artery arises from the common hepatic artery. The largest artery supplying the stomach is the left gastric artery.

Key takeaway:

M/c peptic ulcers : Duodenal ulcers (90% d/t H. pylori & associated with Acid

production).

M/c complication of peptic ulcers : Bleeding.

Duodenal ulcers :

Posterior Ulcers - M/c complication : Bleeding (Vessel : Gastroduodenal artery).

Anterior ulcers - M/c complication: Perforation → Perforation peritonitis.

questions.text: A 26-year female with chronic dyspepsia underwent an urease test, which was positive. What could be the cause?
questions.solution:
H. pylori's Ability to Hydrolyze Urea:
H. pylori hydrolyzes urea, producing ammonia (a strong alkali), which affects antral G cells, causing the release of gastrin via negative feedback. This mechanism leads to modest but inappropriate hypergastrinemia in peptic ulcer disease, potentially causing gastric acid hypersecretion.

Detection of H. pylori:
The organism's urease activity is utilised in diagnostic tests such as:

  • 13C and 14C breath tests
  • CLO test (commercial urease test performed on gastric biopsies)
  • Histological detection methods

Type B Gastritis:
Associated with H. pylori, this form of gastritis primarily affects the antrum of the stomach.

Intestinal Metaplasia and Chronic Pangastritis:

  • Intestinal metaplasia is linked to chronic pangastritis with atrophy.
  • Intestinal metaplasia with dysplasia has malignant potential, which may lead to further complications.

Option A :

Type A gastritis

  • Remember the 4A's associated with type A gastritis:
  • Autoimmune condition: Has circulating antibodies to parietal cells
  • Atrophy of parietal cell mass
  • Achlorhydria: causes chronic hypergastrinemia and microadenomas of enterochromaffin-like (ECL) cells
  • Anaemia: leads to pernicious anaemia, due to malabsorption of Vit B12 (as intrinsic factor is also produced by parietal cells)

Option C : Reflux gastritis is caused by enterogastric reflux.

Option D : Erosions are endoscopically visualised breaks which are confined to the mucosa and do not cause major bleeding due to the absence of arteries and veins in the mucosa. Erosions in the oesophagus, stomach, or duodenum commonly cause mild UGIB, with erosive gastritis and duodenitis accounting for perhaps ~10-15% and erosive esophagitis (primarily due to gastroesophageal reflux disease) ~1-10% of UGIB hospitalizations. The most important cause of gastric and duodenal erosions is NSAID use: ~50% of patients who chronically ingest NSAIDs may have gastric erosions.

Key Takeaway :

questions.text: A patient with peptic ulcer perforation underwent the following surgery. Identity the surgical procedure in image:
questions.solution:
• The procedure shown in the image is Billroth l gastrectomy.
  • Billroth I gastrectomy: The lower half of the stomach is removed, and the cut stomach is anastomosed to the first part of the duodenum.

  • Option B : Billroth II gastrectomy: Following resection,the distal end of the stomach is narrowed by the closure of the lesser curve aspect of the remnant. The greater curve aspect is then anastomosed, usually in a retrocolic fashion,to the jejunum.
  • Option C :

Braun gastrectomy 3 Parts :

  • Partial gastrectomy: A portion of the stomach is removed, typically the lower part.
  • Billroth II reconstruction: The remaining stomach is connected to the jejunum (a part of the small intestine) using an end-to-side anastomosis.
  • Braun's anastomosis: A specific type of intestinal connection is used to prevent reflux of stomach contents into the oesophagus.
  • Option D : Roux-en Y gastrojejunostomy 2 Parts :

Gastric Sleeve or Bypass: The procedure often begins with either a gastric sleeve or gastric bypass operation, which reduces the size of the stomach.

Roux-en-Y Reconstruction: The small intestine is divided into two sections. One section is reconnected to the stomach, creating a new pathway for food. The other section is reconnected to the first section, forming a Y-shaped configuration. This Y-shaped configuration helps regulate the passage of food and prevents reflux.

Key Takeaway :

The lower half of the stomach is removed, and the cut stomach is anastomosed to the first part of the duodenum Is done in Billroth 1 Gastrectomy.

questions.text: Professor Binoy asks about the structure that is used to differentiate upper gastrointestinal bleeding and lower gastrointestinal bleeding. what is that structure?
questions.solution:
• The ligament of Treitz is part of the duodenojejunal junction and forms the line of demarcation for gastrointestinal (GI) bleeding.
  • Upper GI bleeding refers to bleeding proximal to the ligament of Treitz, and lower GI bleeding refers to bleeding distal to the ligament of Treitz.

Option A: Ampulla of Vater is located in the second part of duodenum.

Option C: Hepatic Flexure located at Junction of Ascending and Transverse colon.

Option D: Splenic Flexure is located at the Junction of descending and Transverse colon.

Key Takeaway :

The ligament of Treitz is part of the duodenojejunal junction and forms the line of demarcation for gastrointestinal (GI) bleeding. Upper GI bleeding refers to bleeding proximal to the ligament of Treitz, and lower GI bleeding refers to bleeding distal to the ligament of Treitz.

questions.text: Which of the following classification is used for the endoscopic appearance of bleeding peptic ulcers?
questions.solution:

Option B : The Glasgow-Blatchford bleeding score(GBS) is a screening tool to assess the likelihood that a patient with an acute upper gastrointestinal bleeding (UGIB) will need medical intervention such as a blood transfusion or endoscopic intervention. It incorporates the patient's blood urea level,haemoglobin level, blood pressure, and other clinical parameters.

Option C : Rockall Score assesses the risk of rebleeding and in-hospital mortality in patients with upper GI bleed.

Option D : The Bismuth-Corlette classification system provides an anatomic description of the tumour location and longitudinal extension in the biliary tree.

Key Takeaway :

Forrest classification is clinically very significant as it provides prognostic information to the surgeon about the need for endoscopic therapeutic intervention and the risk of rebleeding.

questions.text: Which of the following statements regarding gastric volvulus is false?
questions.solution:
Types of Gastric Volvulus

  • Organoaxial (Longitudinal Axis):
    • Acute presentation
    • Associated with diaphragmatic defect
  • Mesenteroaxial (Vertical Axis):
    • Partial rotation (<180 degrees)
    • Recurrent
    • Not associated with diaphragmatic defect

Pathophysiology

  • Rotation of the stomach around its axis between the cardia and pylorus
  • Organoaxial volvulus is more common
  • Often associated with paraesophageal herniation

Clinical Presentation

  • Chronic: Difficulty in eating
  • Acute: Ischemia, abdominal pain, vomiting
  • Endoscopy: May be difficult to identify anatomy

Diagnosis

  • Contrast radiograph: Superior for visualising anatomy.
  • Treatment: The stomach is reduced and uncoiled through a transabdominal approach.

Option A : Torsion occurs along the longitudinal axis(organoaxial) of the stomach in two-thirds of the cases whereas along the vertical axis (mesenteroaxial) in one third.

Hence Mesenteroaxial common is a false option.

Option B : Organoaxial gastric volvulus occurs acutely and is associated with a diaphragmatic defect.

Option C : An acute presentation with ischaemia may occur. Endoscopically, it can be extremely difficult to identify the anatomy, and this is one situation in which the contrast radiograph is superior.

Option D :

Borchardt triad:seen in gastric volvulus

  • Sudden-onset severe upper abdominal pain
  • Recurrent retching with production of little vomitus
  • Inability to pass a nasogastric (NG) tube

Key Takeaway:

questions.text: The motility of the gastrointestinal tract is modulated by its intrinsic nervous system. Critical in this process is the migrating motor complex (MMC). Which of the following is true about MMC?
questions.solution:
Migrating Motor Complex (MMC)

  • A cyclic, recurring motility pattern occurring in the stomach and small intestine during fasting.
  • Interrupted by feeding.
  • Essential for clearing residual food and preventing bacterial overgrowth.

Phases:

  1. Phase I: Quiet period with minimal activity.
  2. Phase II: Irregular, low-amplitude contractions.
  3. Phase III: Most active phase with a burst of contractions originating from the antrum or duodenum and migrating distally.
  4. Phase IV: Return to quiescence.

Control Mechanisms:

  • Hormonal Regulation:
    • Motilin: Stimulates phase III contractions.
    • Ghrelin: Stimulates phase III contractions.
    • Somatostatin: Inhibits phase III contractions.
  • Neural Control:
    • Enteric Nervous System: Coordinates MMC activity.
    • Vagus Nerve: Plays a role in controlling MMC activity in the stomach.

Clinical Significance:

  • Delayed or Absent MMC: Associated with gastroparesis and intestinal pseudo-obstruction.
  • Enhanced MMC: May contribute to diarrhoea and irritable bowel syndrome.
  • Pharmacological Modulation: Used to treat gastrointestinal disorders like gastroparesis.

Option A: In the fasting state, there is a period of quiescence in the small bowel, lasting for approximately 40 minutes. There follows a series of waves, also lasting for about 40 minutes, propagating from the fundus of the stomach in a caudal direction at a rate of about 3 per minute (phase II).

Option B : Duodenal slow waves are generated in the duodenum at a rate of about 10 per minute, which carry down the small bowel.

Option D: The amplitude of these contractions increases to a maximum in phase ll, which lasts for about 10 minutes This 90-minute cycle of activity is then repeated. 

Key Takeaway:

Migratory Motor Complex (MMC) :

  • Fasting state motility pattern.
  • Migrates from stomach to colon → Cleanse GIT (Sweeper).
  • 1 MMC once every 90 minutes.
  • Regulated by motilin.

questions.text: Which is the most common early complication following gastric bypass?
questions.solution:
The most common early complication following gastric bypass is an anastomotic leak.

Other Early Complications:

  • Bleeding
  • Infection
  • Venous Thromboembolism
  • Intestinal Obstruction
  • Anastomotic Strictures
  • Marginal Ulcers

Key Takeaway:

Intra Abdominal bleed is the most common early complication following gastric bypass with an incidence of 2-3%.
